item.title: Research
Publications
item.description: For a full list, please check my publications on the SAO/NASA Astrophysics Data System. My name appears as “Chong-Chong He” in publications. Papers under review Link to heading 8 C.-C. He, B. D. Wibking, and M. R. Krumholz, “An Asymptotically-Correct Implicit-Explicit Time Integration Scheme for Finite Volume Radiation-Hydrodynamics”, MNRAS under review, arXiv preprint:2404.08247 (2024) 7 C.-C. He and M. Ricotti, “Formation of large circumstellar discs in multi-scale, ideal-mhd simulations of magnetically critical pre-stellar cores”, MNRAS under review, arXiv preprint: 2403.

item.title: Research
item.description: Research interests: star formation, star cluster dynamics, prestellar cores, epoch of reionization, radiation-hydrodynamic code, n-body code, computational astrophysics. Ongoing Work: Effects of Magnetic Fields on the Formation of Circumstellar Disks Link to heading Magnetic field lines threading a massive circumstellar disk. Massive Prestellar Cores and Formation of Turbulent Circumstellar Disks Link to heading There should have been a video here but your browser does not seem to support it. The formation of high-mass stars remains an active area of study, with two main theoretical models proposed.

item.title: Tips on working on remote linux computers
item.description: Remote Linux environments often require a different set of tools compared to local desktop environments, especially when it comes to file management and navigation. Here are some utilities that can enhance your remote file browsing and editing experience: tmux Link to heading tmux is a convenient tool that allows you to split your terminal window into multiple panes, making it easier to manage multiple sessions or tasks simultaneously. This is especially useful when working remotely, as you can have a file browser open in one pane while editing files or running commands in another.

item.title: Guia de Sintaxe Markdown
item.description: Esse artigo é um exemplo básico para mostrar a sintaxe Markdown que é usada nos arquivos de conteúdo do Hugo. Ele também mostrar como cada elemento básico HTML é estilizado com CSS com os temas do Hugo.

item.title: Markdown Syntax Guide
item.description: This article offers a sample of basic Markdown syntax that can be used in Hugo content files, also it shows whether basic HTML elements are decorated with CSS in a Hugo theme.

item.title: Conteúdo Rico
item.description:
O Hugo vem com vários Shortcodes Internos para conteúdo rico, assim como uma Configuração de Privacidade e uma gama de Shortcodes simples que permitem embutir versões estáticas e sem JS de várias de redes sociais.

Link to heading

item.title: Rich Content
item.description:
Hugo ships with several Built-in Shortcodes for rich content, along with a Privacy Config and a set of Simple Shortcodes that enable static and no-JS versions of various social media embeds.

Link to heading

item.description:

item.title: Configuração de Equações Matemáticas
item.description: Em um projeto Hugo as Notações Matemáticas podem ser usadas com a ajuda de bibliotecas JavaScript de terceiros.

item.title: Math Typesetting
item.description: Mathematical notation in a Hugo project can be enabled by using third party JavaScript libraries.

item.title: HTML and CSS only tabs
item.description: Shortcodes Link to heading The following content: {{< tabgroup >}} {{< tab name="Hello" >}} Hello World! {{< /tab >}} {{< tab name="Goodbye" >}} Goodbye Everybody! {{< /tab >}} {{< /tabgroup >}} Will generate: Hello Hello World! Goodbye Goodbye Everybody! Right alighment Link to heading You can also align the tabs to the right: {{< tabgroup align="right" >}} {{< tab name="Hello" >}} Hello World! {{< /tab >}} {{< tab name="Goodbye" >}} Goodbye Everybody!

item.title: HTML and CSS only tabs
item.description: Shortcodes Link to heading O seguinte conteúdo: {{< tabgroup >}} {{< tab name="Hello" >}} Hello World! {{< /tab >}} {{< tab name="Goodbye" >}} Goodbye Everybody! {{< /tab >}} {{< /tabgroup >}} Irá gerar: Hello Hello World! Goodbye Goodbye Everybody! Alinhamento à direita Link to heading Você também pode alinhas as tabs à direita: {{< tabgroup align="right" >}} {{< tab name="Hello" >}} Hello World! {{< /tab >}} {{< tab name="Goodbye" >}} Goodbye Everybody!

item.title: Mermaid JS support
item.description: If you want to use Mermaid-JS on your website. Provide mermaid as Shortcode in your markdown file. flowchart LR A --> B B --> C C --> D D --> B sequenceDiagram participant Alice participant Bob Alice->>Bob: Hi Bob Bob->>Alice: Hi Alice Find more example on Mermaid-JS website.

item.title: Mermaid JS support
item.description: Se quiser usar o Mermaid-JS em sua página. Use o shortcode mermaid em seus conteúdos Markdown. flowchart LR A --> B B --> C C --> D D --> B sequenceDiagram participant Alice participant Bob Alice->>Bob: Hi Bob Bob->>Alice: Hi Alice Entro mais exemplos na página do Mermaid-JS.

item.title: Fun with Julia
item.description: I am a strong advocate of Julia, a new programming language for scientific computing. Julia combines the speed of C/Fortran with the user-friendliness of Python. In this first demonstration, I wrote a one-dimentional hydrodynamic code. This simulation, along with the plotting and animation, was produced entirely from a single Julia script, as demonstrated below. Download script. using Parameters using Plots using Printf """ A struct to store all parameters and data of the grids """ @with_kw mutable struct Grid nx::Int ng::Int t = 0.

item.title: ASTR101, Spring 2021
item.description: This is a webpage for ASTR101 (Spring 2021), Sections 0109 and 0110, of whom I am the TA. I will post useful links, announcements, lab solutions, etc., here. Table of contents Table of contents Links and Files Announcements Discussions Discussion #1 (Feb 3) Discussion #2 (Feb 10) Discussion #3 (Feb 17) Discussion #4 (Feb 24) Discussion #5 (Mar 3) Discussion #6 (Mar 10) Discussion #7 (Mar 24) Discussion #8 (Mar 31) Discussion #9 (Apr 7) Discussion #10 (Apr 14) Discussion #11 (Apr 21) Discussion #12 (Apr 28) Discussion #13 (May 5) Labs Lab #0 (Jan 28) Lab #1 (Feb 4) - Mathematical Tools Lab #2 (Feb 11) - Phases of the Moon Lab #3 (Mar 11) - Moons of Jupiter Lab #4 (Feb 25) - Planetary Surface Features Lab #5 (Mar 4) - Sky Motions Lab #6 - Spectroscopy Lab #7 (Apr 1) - Exoplanets Lab #8 (Apr 8) - Stellar Spectra Additional Lab Instructions Lab #9 (Apr 15) - Measuring Parallax Lab #10 (Apr 22) - Galaxies Lab #11 (Apr 29) - Expansion of the Universe Links and Files Discussion & Lab Syllabus Survey: ASTR101-0109/0111 Lab/Discussion Groups Announcements Lab #1 is graded and the answer key is posted.

item.title: Why you should never use 'jet' colormap
item.description: Compare “viridis” and “jet” with “gray” colormap Link to heading Here I create an artificial Gaussian density profile, centering at the origin and having a $\sigma$ of 0.5, and show it with “gray” colormap. from __future__ import division, print_function import numpy as np import matplotlib.pyplot as plt # construct a 2D Gaussian x = np.linspace(-3, 3, 200) y = x X, Y = np.meshgrid(x, y) d = np.sqrt(X*X + Y*Y) sigma, mu = .

item.title: ASTR100, Fall 2017
item.description: <!DOCTYPE html> ASTR100: Solutions to Selected Discussion Questions ASTR100 Introduction to Astronomy Hello, everyone... I'm ChongChong He, the TA of ASTR100 (Sections 0104 and 0105). I am here to guide you toward a better understanding of astronomy. This website is used to privode solutions to homework and discussion problems, presentation slides, useful information, and materials that I use in the discussion. The syllabus for our discussion is available here. Discussion Meet Time: Fri 10:00-10:50am (0104) 11:00-11:50am (0105) Location: ATL 2400 Office Hours Time: Mon 3:30-4:30 pm, Wed 11:00 am-12:00 pm Location: PSC 1238 Section Policy Please show up for your discussion.
TBD

item.title: About Me
item.description: I am a postdoctoral fellow at the Research School of Astronomy & Astrophysics of the Australian National University. My research focuses on exploring the laws of star formation in galaxies and their role in shaping the universe through simulations on supercomputers. Currently, I am developing a new radiation-hydrodynamic code that fully utilizes the GPUs on the largest supercomputers in the world. Before joining ANU, I obtained my PhD degree in Astronomy from the University of Maryland.

item.title: Classical Music
item.description: Over the years I have been obsessed with classical music, particularly classical piano works. Who is my favorite composer? Link to heading Ludwig van Beethoven. My other favorite composers are Frédéric Chopin, Franz Liszt, Johann Sebastian Bach, Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky, and more. What are my favorite Beethoven works? Link to heading Check this melodic, lively, and magnificent piece: Piano Concerto No. 5 “Emperor” this powerful piece: Symphony No. 5 in C minor “Fate”

item.title: Contact
item.description: My email address is chongchong.he@anu.edu.au . My inbox is always open. Whether you have a question or just want to say hi, I’ll try my best to get back to you!

item.title: News
item.description: April 2023 I defended my Ph.D. thesis in April, 2023. I will be joining the Australian National University as a postdoctoral fellow at the Research School of Astronomy & Astrophysics and work with Professor Mark Krumholz. June 2021 I am awarded the Future Investigators in NASA Earth and Space Science and Technology (FINESST)! March 2021 I am awarded an Ann G. Wylie Dissertation Fellowship!

item.title: Teaching
item.description: Courses I taught as a teaching assistant: ASTR101 - General Astronomy, Spring 2021 ASTR100 - Introduction to Astronomy, Fall 2017 Galaxies, Cosmology, Origin of the Universe, Stars and Stellar Systems, Solar System Astronomy, and Life in the Universe, 2016-2018
